msDesc.head: Didactic miscellany, containing a bestiary and other texts

summary.seg: This manuscript is one of a small group of examples containing an uncommon textual recension. Minor variant readings of this manuscript prove that its text is the most faithful to that of the lost archetype among all the bestiary recensions. It is most similar to Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum, MS 254 in many aspects and was very probably copied from the same lost archetype. The main departures of Kk.4.25 from the Fitzwilliam bestiary are a slight change in the chapter order and the presence of two chapters of strictly didactic character that has no relation to the typical content of the bestiaries: Quattuor modis peccatum ('The Four Ways it is Sinful') and Quattuor colores caelestis ('The Four Heavenly Colours').

These two chapters appear after the chapter on the ibis. The first texts comes from Gregory the Great with some variations and paraphrases, while the second is a free paraphrase of Isidore of Seville's text on the rainbow (arcus). Both chapters appear in the cluster of content on birds, which was taken from a different textual version of the bestiary. The cluster includes the following birds: ibis, phoenix, ostrich, coot, halcyon. Hence, Kk.4.25 has these additional chapters on the these birds as well as the chapters typical of this group. Further, Kk.4.25 contains a chapter on the bird hoopoe, concludes the section on birds with the chapter on the peridexion tree, and contains a chapter on the hydrus, none of which appear in other manuscipts of this group. All of these additions came from a manuscript very similar to London, British Library, Add. MS 11283.

Another important textual peculiarity of Kk.4.25 is an addition from a text concerning the symbolism and morals of classical mythology for a Christian audience by the so-called Vatican Mythographer III. These inclusions may indicate that by the time Kk.4.25 was written, the tradition of this version of the text still was not stable, further evidence that this group's archtype may date to not long before this manuscript was created.

The bestiary in Kk.4.25 is one of eighteen texts intended to be bound together. In its original condition, the manuscript probably included even more. Thus, this manuscript is one of the few large miscellanies that include a bestiary. The nature of all these texts is strictly didactic, leading to the conclusion that the manuscript was used as a teaching tool in a cathedral school or monastery.

In terms of its programme of illuminations, Kk.4.25 is a masterpiece of bestiary imagery, often overlooked in discussions of the most beautiful examples. The iconography of this manuscript is the closest to the Fitzwilliam's, although it has many of its own motifs and variants. The illustrations in the bestiary and other sections are the works of several different artists. As one scholar has pointed out, the style of the illustrations is unusually monumental, as is exemplified in the rendering of the sea creature, and might be linked with wall painting models, for example the painted chamber of Westminster Palace. The troughed folds and angular poses of some of the figures in Kk.4.25 bestiary are reminiscent of some later sculptures in Westminster Abbey. Another iconographic link pointing to London may be found in the cross-legged king and an image of David wearing a crown in the psalter produced in this region (New York, Morgan Library and Museum, MS M.25, folio 4).

The manuscript has numerous unique illustrations. The mutilated folio 52 now preserves only two framed illustrations from the so-called Monstrous Races section, of an Antipode and of Bragmanni holding a scroll with text from John of Salisbury's Policraticus in their hands: Divitas non habemus quarum cupiditate nos expugnare debeas ('We do not possess wealth, [otherwise] out of greed, you would want to conquer us'). It seems that the manuscript has lost the scene of Adam Naming the Animals that usually follows Marvels of the East in this textual recension. In the illustration to the chapters on the wether, ram, sheep and lamb, above the shepherd's head is an inscription in Anglo-Norman French, testifying to the artist's sense of humour: Ha ha ware le corn ('Ha ha beware of horns') (folio 58v). The chapter on the stag in Kk.4.25, like that in the Fitzwilliam bestiary, illustrates the story of the stags crossing a river, each with its chin on the back of the one in front of it. The illustration of this motif is rare: as far as I know, only one bestiary (Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 53, f. 192r) has such a scene. In the chapter on the dog, Kk.4.25 is missing the first leaf and now shows two scenes. The first consists of two registers with perhaps unique illustrations of Jason's dog refusing food near the beheaded corpse of its master, and Lysimachus's dog throwing itself on the funeral pyre, both demonstrating their great loyalty. The next scene is an illustration of armed Albanian men guided by a dog that traced the robber who had stolen their ox. In the chapter on the asp, the face of the charmer seems to have been modeled on that of the rider in the dromedary chapter in London, British Library, Harley MS 3244, f. 48r.

Another unique illustration can be found in the chapter on the squirrel, called cyrogrillus, in which an artist of Kk.4.25 represents two scenes: the first shows the squirrel cracking a nut at the top of the tree, while in the second the squirrel is displayed apparently intending to cross the river on a sort of raft full of shells. The chapter on Four Heavenly Colours, an atypical text for a bestiary as mentioned above, is illustrated with an image of a rainbow.

Other examples of rarely seen approaches to ilumination can be seen in Kk.4.25's illustrations of the Hydra and the Gorgon: at the bottom of f. 68v is a fragment of waves that seems to be from an illustration of Scylla. After that, on f. 69r, are two scenes of sirens. The first shows three sirens, a scene that is rare (analagous examples occur in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Douce 88 and MS Bodley 602); the second scene is mutilated an presents a ship with sailors who have sirens' hands on their necks and heads. While the composition is rare in English bestiaries (I am aware only of Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Bodley 764, f. 74v having a similar one), it is common in vernacular French bestiaries, for example bestiaries of Richard de Fournival and Guillaume le Clerc. Finally, the artist of Kk.4.25 illustrates the hippocentaur with a bow and the onocentaur with a shield and a club. The manuscript is incomplete, as it is missing the images of Cerberus, Chimera, and the centaur that conclude the Westminster manuscript (London, Westminster Abbey, MS 22).

msItem.incipit: f. 1rAb aquilone fulgur
msItem.explicit: f. 18v Uictus et extinctus herebi penetralia scandit

msItem.incipit: 19r: Semper memor tui etiam inter dubia bellorum
msItem.explicit: 25v: et animi industrie optime aristotiles indicium
msItem.finalRubric: 25v: Explicit epistola Alexandri ad Aristotileo preceptorem suum

msItem.title: Historia Alexandri magni
msItem.incipit: 25r: Egyptii sapientes fati diuino genere primi feruntur
msItem.explicit: 25r: penetral regieque secreta . Ibi se solita

msItem.title: Historia Alexandri magni
msItem.rubric: 27r: Incipit hystoria alexandri magni regis macedonium
msItem.incipit: 27r: Egyptii sapientes fati diuino genere primi feruntur
msItem.explicit: 38v: uino et ueneno superatus atque extinctus occubuit

msItem.author: Alanus ad Insulis
msItem.title: De sex alis cherubim
msItem.rubric: 39r: Incipit tractatus Magistri Alani de sex alis cherubim
msItem.incipit: 39v: Prima ala est confessio . Confessio duplex est
msItem.explicit: 38v: et illud aspiciens quod aspiciendum est

msItem.title: Revelatio sancti Michaelis in Monte Gargano
msItem.incipit: 44r: ut m,uneta que persummum sue sedis ministrum conferre dignatus est
msItem.explicit: 44v: et illud aspiciens quod aspiciendum est
msItem.finalRubric: 44v: [E]xplicit reuelatio sancti michaelis archangeli in monte gargano

msItem.rubric: incipit eiusdem [sancti michaelis] reuelacio in monte tumba . xviio kalends nouembris
msItem.incipit: 44v: Postquam gens francorum christi gratia insignita
msItem.explicit: 47r: crescente religionis amore fidelium excruxit manus ubi prestantur diuina beneficia . adiuuante domino nostro qui est benedictus in secula seculorum . Amen

msItem.title: Excerpts
msItem.note: Citations from Gregorius Magnus, Homiliae, Hugh of St Victor De sacramentis, etc, on the properties of angels.

msItem.title: Excerpts
msItem.note: Excerpts from John of Salisbury, Policraticus (Book 2, Prologue) and Hugh of St Victor, Didascalion (Book 3, Chapter 13).

msItem.author: Isidore of Seville
msItem.title: Etymologiae
msItem.incipit: 51v: Cum uoluntas conditoris cuiusque condite rei natura sit
msItem.explicit: 52v: -ctissime princeps prelia tua (...) subsecutam . Sed quid (...) -fficit orbis

msItem.title: Bestiary [Latin]
msItem.incipit: 55r: Omnibus animantium adam primus uocabula indidit
msItem.explicit: 100v: Sit procuratores uel officiales recenter substituti ; acrius insubditos deseuiunt

msItem.title: Quattuor modis peccatum
msItem.author: Gregory the Great
msItem.incipit: 81r: Quatuor modis peccatum perpetratur in corde [quatuor] consumatur
msItem.explicit: 81r: uel obstinacionis misere desperationis enutritur
msItem.note: Excerpt, with some variations and paraphrases.

msItem.title: Quattuor colores caelestis
msItem.author: Isidore of Seville
msItem.incipit: 81v: Quatuor colores celestis arcus habet . i . igneum . purpureum . album . et nigrum
msItem.explicit: 81v: Qui crediderit et baptizatus fuerit saluus erit
msItem.note: Paraphrase of Isidore's text on the rainbow

msItem.title: De septem miraculis mundi ab hominibus factis
msItem.incipit: 101r: Primum de septem mirabilibus mundi est capitolium rome
msItem.explicit: 101v: Et super sexaginta quatuor ; centum uiginti octo columpne faciunt finem . tam mirabilis edificii

msItem.incipit: Sunt lapides igni feri in quodam monte orientis
msItem.explicit: 101v: copiosus ex ambobus ignis consurgit

msItem.author: John of Salisbury
msItem.title: Policraticus
msItem.rubric: 101v: Omnia varia esse et res ex side sua cui respondere . Ex policratico iohannis
msItem.incipit: 101v: In creatoris prorumpit iniuriam ; quicumque ex constellationibus
msItem.explicit: 104v: Omnia maiestas sua continet atque potestas . Item stabilisque manens dat cuncta moueri

msItem.rubric: 105r: De remediis fortuitorum bonorum conferunt inter se . Callio et senecca
msItem.author: Pseudo-Seneca the Younger
msItem.title: De remediis fortuitorum
msItem.incipit: 105r:Callio . Dolor iminet . Seneca . Si exiguus est feramus leuis est patiencia
msItem.explicit: 108r: Nulla est sepulatura . Non sepeliemur ; sed proiciemur
msItem.note: With additions to the text and in different order to that printed in Haase.

msItem.author: Isidore of Seville
msItem.title: Etymologiae
msItem.incipit: 108v: Arborum nomen siue herbarum ab arius inflexum creditur
msItem.explicit: 110r: unde scriptura . scribe in buxo

msItem.incipit: 110r-113v: Phisilogus dicit . Est lapis qui dicitur adamans et in quodam monte orientis inuenitur
msItem.explicit: 113v: Urinatores qui sursum sunt ; chorum sanctorum signant
msItem.finalRubric: 113v: Explicit liber de naturis bestiarum et de qualitatibus eorumdem

msItem.incipit: 113v: Nos primum pueris ponit natura magistram
msItem.explicit: 113v: Sed deus est et homo quam satur figurat ymago

msItem.author: Marbod of Rennes
msItem.title: Liber lapidum
msItem.rubric: 114r: Incipiunt versus Marbodi de lapidibus numero sexaginta
msItem.incipit: 114r: Evax rex arabum legitur scripsisse neroni
msItem.explicit: : Inter sanctorum agmina . cananius dom cantica

msItem.title: De uiribus herbarum
msItem.rubric: 121r: Incipit liber Macri de naturis herbarum

foliation.note: Folio numbers 26, 42-43, 53-54, 57, 68, 72 and 107 assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume, according to the interpretation of the manuscript's collation (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library). However, in the case of Quire 7, the foliation does not correctly tally with the structure of the quire.
Numbering in pencil in upper right-hand corner of the rectos, by H.L. Pink (Assistant Under-Librarian 1947-1960 and Head of the Department of Manuscripts, 1960-1970).

list.item: Quire 78-3 (ff. 51-58: 2nd leaf, f. 52, mutilated; 3rd and 4th leaves, ff. 53 and 54, missing; no leaf missing between ff. 58 and 59 (contrary to collation by H.L. Pink); 8th leaf, after f. 58, missing)
Quire 18two(ff. 133-134: rest of the quire missing)

collation.catchwords: Catchwords almost all trimmed away, except for ff. 108v and 116v.

layoutDesc.layout:
Written space 210 145
Pricked in the inner and outer margins; usually mostly trimmed along the outer margin. Ruled in plummet. Single vertical bounding lines extending to the top of the page and into the lower margin; first and second horizontal lines extending the full width of the page, and horizonatal lines transversing the central margin; penultimate and last horizontal lines extending into the margin and occasionally the full width of the page.

decoDesc.decoNote:
Miniatures ranging from 2/3-page illustrations (framed, line-drawn, tinted or fully and thickly coloured, some gilded) to 2-line images (generally simpler, tinted) of birds or fish (some mutilated).
18v: Alexander the Great enthroned cross-legged as armipotens with caption above of twelve hexameters
39r: blank space, probably intended for moralized cherub of De sex aliis, filled with (?)apotropaic compass pattern in ink
47r: poorly traced copy of the Annunication
47v: Annunciation: St Gabriel on the left with right arm raised in blessing, and the Virgin Mary on the right, standing and holding a book
48r: Tobit, seated with staff to the right, being cured by St Raphael, standing to the left with right arm outstretched and index and middle fingers touching Tobit's eyes
50v: St Michael, unfinished (bust and right arm only), with later additions
52r: antipod; twelve-footed people (both fragmentary; leaf mutilated)
52v: Bragmanni (fragmentary; leaf mutilated)
56v: ox; man holding a decorated horn in the lower left-hand margin; later crude imitation of the man holding a horn in the lower margin
58r: buffalo with curled horns and nose-ring; bull with yoke around neck and two cows
58v: flock of sheep and rams, two of which are butting heads, and a shepherd with right arm outstretched and holding a crook, a horn strung around his neck, and a lamb in his left arm, exclaiming "ha ha ware le corn"
59r: wild ass
60v: mule
61r: camel
61v: dromedary; three stags
62r: four stags crossing a river in order to find food, swimming in a line with their heads resting on the rear of the animal in front, the first stag feeding from a tree
62v: fallow deer
63r: she-goat
63v: boar being hunted and attacked by hounds
65r: leopard; lynx
65v: dragon in cave, panther, two stags and a deer
66r: bear
66v: unicorn lying in the arms of a virgin, being slaughtered by a huntsman, with his horse standing by (in the space left for depiction of the rhinoceros)
67r: monoceros
67v: tigress fooled by a glass sphere thrown by a hunter mounted on a horse stealing her cub; griffin devouring a man
69v: manticore
70r: parandrus; yale
70v: apes (one holding young) pursued by a hunter holding a net and blowing a horn (imperfect: right-hand portion of the miniature lacking owing to damage to the leaf); marmoset (in lower margin)
71r: fox tricking birds by pretending to be dead
71v: hyena devouring an animal; hyena feeding on a human corpse
73r: in two horizontal registers: death of Jason by beheading, his dog pining; King Lysimachus joined by his dog on a funeral pyre
73v: within a single miniature: to the left, a crowd of men, one blowing a horn and another with a dog on a leash that has discovered a thief; in the middle, the thief is leading away a bull and carrying a pole-axe, but is being apprehended by another man holding a sword; to the right, the thief is hanged
74r: two hares; dog chasing a porcupine (with later crude copying below)
74v: rabbit being chased by a weasel; melo; two cats with two mice; mice feeding; weasel chasing a lizard
75r: mole; dormouse (in margin); red squirrel in a tree cracking a nut (in margin); grey squirrel perched on a raft of shells (in margin)
75v: two hedgehogs, one rolling on its back to collect food; ants; ants emerging from anthills and feeding on crops (lower margin)
76r: hydra (mutilated)
76v: three gorgons holding an eye, spectators (in margin) turned to stone
77r: three sirens lulling sailors to sleep with their music (mutilated)
77v: hippocentaur with bow and arrow; onocentaur with club and shield
78v: later crude copying of an eagle
79v: eagle; vulture
80r: two cranes; stork
80v: swan, bittern; heron; ibis
81r: ibis feeding young in the nest
81v: rainbow; ostrich holding an egg on the ground in its beak; coot
82r: kingfisher (with later addition); phoenix in the fire, beneath a sun
82v: phoenix
83r: two caladrius, perched on bed-sheets, with a man lying in bed; seagull
83v: ericenea (with later crude copy); coot with nest in water; quail; heron
84r: duck; parrot; pelicans
84v: hoopoe; bee-eaters; hawk; kite; two partridges
85r: cinnamolgus in nest atop a tree (trimmed away) with a man beneath with a sling; hoopoe with young pecking its plumage (with later crude tracing in lower margin)
85v: later crude tracing of man with a sling; magpie; jackdaw; cuckoo; raven; crow
86r: jackdaw; bats; little owl; tawny owl
86v: owl; two nightingales; turtledove; pigeon; crested lark
87r: crow; swallow; blackbird
87v: various birds; peacock; cockerel and hen
88r: later crude copy of hen (in lower margin)
88v: perindeus tree with pigeons among the branches and dragon beneath
89r: (?)walrus (in space for fish or baleen whale)
89v: whale being hunted and caught by whalers, one astride the animal and hammering a stopper into its blow-hole
90r: dolphin
90v-92r: various fish, shells and molluscs (including crude later copy of a fish in the lower margin of 90v)
92v: seal; hippopotamus
93r: two sea serpents
93v: dragon; weasel biting a basilisk (with crude later copy in lower margin)
94r: viper
94v: asp before a man holding a scroll inscribed "Super aspidem et Basiliscum"; three types of snake
95r: five types of snake
95v: boa biting and feeding from the udders of a cow; seven types of snake
96r: five types of lizard; toad; salamander; salamander eating fruit from a tree with a man lying below, poisoned
96v: two types of lizard; serpent shedding its skin
97v: worm; spider in its web; leech
98r: scorpion; caterpillar eating foliage
98v: centipede; snail; silkworm; maggots
99r: beehive, bees and two beekeepers
101v: two fiery stones enclosing the heads of a man and a woman
113v: King Evax sitting at a desk, writing
120v: Marbod of Rennes sitting, writing (unfinished)
126v: Bernardus Silvestris sitting, writing (unfinished, with later crude additions)

decoNote.p: Eleven-line gold initial with red and green decorative infill (f. 44v).
Seven-line burnished gold initial on purple ground, with green, blue, orange and rose decorative infill (f. 51v).
Six-line parti-coloured burnished gold and red initial with red infill (f. 39v).
Four-line burnished gold initial on purple ground with blue and orange floral infill (f. 55r).
Numerous one- to three-line red, green or blue penwork initials, often flourished in contrasting colours.

additions.p: Throughout the manuscript, minor marginal annotations by a hand of the 13th century.
12r-15v: marginal annotations by a hand of the second half of the 14th century.
Numerous pen trials and full or partial alphabets, by various hands of the 16th and early 17th centuries, largely at the beginning of the manuscript.

binding.p: Full goatskin, red. Douglas Cockerell and Son, Letchworth, 1967 (stamp on skin on inside of right-hand board with monogram 'SE', presumably Sandy Cockerell and his wife Elizabeth).
Blind-tooled calfskin binding, with rectangular frame and central panel stamp in gold.

According to an inscription on the pastedown preserved from the previous binding on the right cover, inner, this former binding was "Repaired at the British Museum (Messrs Eyre and Spottiswoode) July-October 1911. Former binding retained and now kept with the manuscript. Formerly bound with printed Hortus sanitatis (Strasbourg, 1536), now CUL, N*.8.41.

history.provenance: Annotations by various 16th- or early 17th-century hands, including the names "Antony Byers" (56v), "Peter" (109v-110r), (?)"Marke Barne" (131v).
One of the manuscripts of Richard Holdsworth, Master of Emmanuel College (1590-1649).
history.acquisition: Acquired by the University Library in July 1664: no. 1 in the inventory of Holdsworth's manuscripts compiled by William Crowe (MS Ff.4.27 / Dd.8.45).

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on unpublished MS notes by M.R. James and the description prepared for Western Illuminated Manuscripts: A Catalogue of the Collection in Cambridge University Library by Paul Binski and Patrick Zutshi, with the collaboration of Stella Panayotova, Cambridge, 2011 (used here by kind permission of Cambridge University Press). The introductory summary is taken from the catalogue entry for the 2019 exhibition Book of Beasts: The Bestiary in the Medieval World, ed. by Elizabeth Morrison with Larisa Grollemond.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions). Contact the Manuscripts Department for further information on the availability of this manuscript
